Award.AwardTitle: Reserve Driver Online Scheduling for Transit Operations

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this award is to develop randomized algorithms to improve utilization of reserve drivers when transit agencies (e.g., bus, light rail, subway, ferry) need to use them to cover work that arises from planned and unplanned absences, bus breakdowns, weather, and special events. The developed algorithms will maximize reward (amount of work assigned to on-call drivers) by trading off the reward that would be realized if a job being considered were assigned to a reserve driver against a potentially higher reward from a future job, which could be rejected on account of the earlier decision. The algorithms will achieve this goal by strategically assigning some work to overtime drivers to improve the overall utilization of reserve drivers. Such decisions will be based on the outcomes of random draws from probability distributions specified by the algorithm. Because the job inter-arrival times and durations vary significantly from one day to the next, average performance based algorithms can perform poorly in many instances. Therefore, developed algorithms will aim to achieve the best performance in the worst-case.

If successful, the research will produce a real-time solution to the reserve driver work assignment problem that guarantees performance no worse than a certain threshold of the best possible performance, where the latter is realized if all pieces of work are known before making work assignments and such assignments are made optimally. It will provide a proof-in-concept for a class of algorithms that include a discretionary parameter, to be selected by the user, whose value will serve to convey the degree of a user's preference for one of two approaches: accept all jobs that can be scheduled, or deploy a randomized algorithm whose recommendation depends on the job length. If successful, the results of this research will serve to automate the reserve-driver dispatch process and make work assignment more efficient, potentially saving transit agencies thousands of dollars daily. Data show relatively poor utilization of reserve drivers (50 to 60 percent range) and simultaneously high expenditures on overtime (of the order of tens of thousand of dollars daily for large transit agencies). More broadly, this work will also contribute to the development of new scheduling approaches in highly random application domains.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Problem Statement and Significance:

Transit agencies (e.g. bus, light rail, subway, ferry) use reserve drivers to cover work that arises from planned and unplanned absences, equipment breakdowns, weather, and special events.  The primary objective of this project was to develop algorithms to improve utilization of reserve drivers and thereby reduce overtime costs. The developed algorithms maximize the amount of work assigned to on-call drivers by trading off the reward (assigned work duration) that would be realized if a job being considered were assigned to a reserve driver against a potentially higher reward from a future job, which could be rejected on account of the earlier decision. What makes this problem difficult is that the characteristics of future jobs (start times and durations) are unknown.

Related objectives of this project include the development of algorithms for online fixed job scheduling problems, which arise in in the gig economy, and in contexts such as scheduling jobs in make-to-order manufacturing systems, and scheduling of surgeries in operating rooms. The PI has explored extensions of the approach developed for reserve driver scheduling to other such application areas.

Students Supported:

The following students were supported either entirely or in part from this award. In some cases, the PI was able to leverage this award to get additional funding for his students (see Other Noteworthy Outcomes).

Peer-Reviewed Manuscripts (published or accepted):

  1. Bandi, C. and Gupta, D. 2019. "Operating-Room Staffing and Online Scheduling," Manufacturing and Service Operations Management, accepted for publication, in press.
  2. Gupta, D., and Li, F. 2016. "Reserve Driver Scheduling." IIE Transactions, 48, 193-204.
  3. Li, F., and Gupta, D. 2014. "The Extraboard Operator Scheduling and Work Assignment Problem." IIE Transactions, 46, 1132-1146.

 Manuscripts Under Review:

  1. Goyal, S. and Gupta, D. "The Online Reservation Problem," Available at SSRN: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3137745 or http://dx.doi.org/10.2139/ssrn.3137745
  2. Goyal, S. and Gupta, D. "The Online Multiple Knapsack Problem," Available at SSRN: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3137277 or http://dx.doi.org/10.2139/ssrn.3137277

Key Results:

  1. For the online interval-scheduling problem when the risk measure falls in an uncertainty set, we show that the search for an optimal online algorithm, in terms of the robust competitive ratio, can be restricted to the set of interval classification algorithms. We prove that the search for optimal interval breakpoints can be reduced to a mixed integer linear program with assignment constraints, which can be solved by available commercial solvers (Publication #1).
  2. For the reserve driver scheduling problem, we demonstrate that our algorithms' worst-case performance guarantees are as good as those of previous algorithms proposed in the literature (Publications #2 and #3). Our approach is different because we also consider average performance and test the goodness of our algorithm using real data. We show that our approach can save transit agencies tens of thousands of dollars in overtime costs while delivering same or better on-time performance.
  3. For the online multiple knapsack problem, we derive lower bounds on the CR of any algorithm, analyze CRs of some known algorithms, and propose three new algorithms. We also study the online revenue management problem where all items have sizes equal to the knapsack capacities (Under Review #1).
  4. For the online interval scheduling problem with asynchronous job start times, we obtain a lower bound on the competitive ratio that any algorithm may achieve for this problem setting, and an upper bound on the competitive ratio of our proposed algorithm (Under Review #2). Then, we argue that the upper bound we achieve is good and tight in an asymptotic sense.

Dissemination:

In addition to publications in peer-reviewed journals, and posting of manuscripts on public web sites like SSRN, the work products of this project have been presented at several INFORMS and MSOM conferences in invited sessions, both by the PI and his students.

Other Noteworthy Outcomes:

The project allowed the PI to win an award from the office of Vice President for Research at the University of Minnesota under the auspices of a pilot program to accelerate technology transfer. The purpose of that award was to ensure that some industry participants will spend time in the PI's lab on a regular basis, interacting with the PI and his students. Such efforts by the PI significantly improved the relevance of problems studied and provided his students an opportunity to work alongside practitioners.
